posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hello All,

For those who haven't been paying attention - in which case "tut!" - the nasty boys in the playground are making me construct a cleric in the spirit of Viconia DeVir, beloved of Baldur's Gate. She's a Drow cleric, but has been cast out by Lolth and adopted by Shar - goddess of darkness and loss. She is, in effect, a refugee - but she'd fry your gentleman's sausage on a skillet for describing her as such. Feisty is an understatement.

Now, I've had a furtle about to see what I could come up with - bearing in mind I have never even played a cleric before (I tried Mith's marvelous Blood and Faith in Adam Miller's campaign, but flunked it), let alone built one.

I have been persuaded by Valerfor (and because it makes life easier) that I could build her as human, rather than elf, thus avoiding an xp penalty, so here are my first thoughts... (oh, and thanks, Max, for your little contribution, that just made it worse!)

I'm thinking Lawful Neutral (Viconia is able to be turned to True Neutral in BG ToB, but that won't work with what's coming) Cleric 23/ Monk 9/ CoT 8 (or Champion of Shar, so CoS). My initial stats could be STR 12, DEX 15, CON 10, WIS 16, INT 14, CHA 8. I'm then thinking of taking 14 Cleric and 6 Monk pre-epic - with 9 Cleric/ 3 Monk/ 8 CoT in epic levels. I'm thinking War and one of Destruction/Strength/Magic/Trickery as domains (I would have gone for Sun, but Vicky doesn't know what the sun is).

As far as feats go, having done some browsing it would appear that Extend and Empower Spell are the only big boys from the arcane/divine armoury that really matter. That would seem to leave me with enough pre-epic feats for Weapon Focus (rapier's my current favourite), Weapon Finesse, Imp Crit, Blind Fight and KD (Toughness and Great Fort would be nice, but you can't have everything).

In epic levels, I'm thinking that the 4 BFs from CoT and Cleric should all go into Great WIS, with other feats in EWF, Armour Skin and Epic Prowess. Now, if I'm right (and that is by no means guaranteed) then I've got the 10 stat bonuses to play with, along with 4 more epic feats. I could split them between DEX and WIS or concentrate on one. I have no idea.

In skills, I'm thinking Concentration and Spellcraft, Tumble and Discipline, hopefully with enough left for Spot or Listen, but I haven't done the sums yet.

There, now open for shooting at!

Cheers

EDIT: Sorry, just went for a pee, during which I remembered that I'll be getting KD/IKD anyway, so I can grab one of Toughness or Great Fortitude.

posts.author: Pelagius
posts.content:
Am I allowed to be a bit of a dick here? If so, keep reading, if not, disregard the rest of my post.
...

OK, you're reading. Here's the thing: I've been browsing you guys' BG characters builds and I must say thay all look very well made. However, some of them deviate a lot from the spirit of the original character. I understand that this is done in lieu of powerbuilding, however we have to consider a couple of things:

First, no henchmen in the BG sag were properly optimized from a powergaming (or powerbuilding) prupose, in fact, a lot of them were sub-par and a couple were bellow average or terrible.

Secondly, if we're to make a build based on a BG character we should restrict ourselves to the "spirit" of the character. Indeed, we should try to make the most out of that build, but within the artificial restriction of staying true to the nature of the original character.

As an example: it is perfectly OK (I would say even mandatory) to give Minsc barbarian levels to have him access rage. But it would not be correct to not make him a ranger, since being a ranger is what Minsc was and even affected his dialogue and some subquests in BGII.

In the case of Viconia, as far as I know you can't really take drow as playable race in vanilla NWN, but it would be incorrect, IMO, to make her anything but an elf, regardless of penalties.

In the same venue, while rapiers are probably attractive to such a build (Viconia was known for her high WIS, low STR and CON), it would be against the spirit of the original chracter.

What I mean is, if she's not gonna be an elf, and she's gonna even be wielding rapiers, can you reeally call her Viconia?

I mean no offense, I've no doubt that you can build a very interesting cleric character with what you've got on the table right now... I just don't think it would be ole' Vic.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Pelagius, I agree with you on so many things here. I managed to bite the bullet on elf because I've played Aribeth's Redemption as a human, so managed to rationalize it (I'm not putting another spoiler in, you'll just have to go back to the Minsc!!!..thread) for the purposes of this build.

To be fair, in BG and BG2, Drow males were specialist mages, but females were specialized clerics, which you can't do in NwN, so it was a question of what gives ground. Arguable both ways. Of course, it matters less in a PW where you can bump xp by re-spawning.

I hope you've read all the nonsense this Viconia build came from (started with a malicious ;-) thread from Valerfor in Ye Olde Tavern, then moved to the Minsc!!!... thread). My intention throughout has been to make her as close as I can to her BG2 self.

If I've got original (BG2) Vicky right, her weapon proficiencies are in mace, sling and warhammer. In NwN, I'd be naturally inclined to morning star (and yes, some of that is personal preference). However, in NwN that virtually by necessity would make her a secondary character, given her STR and CON. And where BG is about cultivating an heroic party, you can't do that in NwN. One character is the hero/anti-hero. Thus, in pretty much all of these BG facsimiles, they're optimized for you to play them in a different environment, with different rules.

I suppose I'm saying that compromise is where it's at. And there's certainly no offence taken, my friend. In fact, good to see you again!

[He's not answered any of your questions, has he, precious? No, precious - hit him with a rock]

Cheers!

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Viconia is a dark elf, a drow. If they were implemented as a sub race in Vanilla NwN, the favored class for females would be cleric, with wizard for males. That would have made things much easier for you. Some mods and PWs have drow as a playable subrace with several changes, among them the favored class.

But in most cases you are stuck with the standard NwN races and classes. Choosing elf for a cleric is both possible and playable, but you limit yourself because of the many base classes that lead to an xp penalty.
Of course you can use prestige classes to get what you need, but often it would be more convenient to pick a base class instead.
Going with human is a solution - but a human is not an elf. If one discovered that Viconia had a touch of human blood from one of the sex slaves of her ancestors, you could build with 1/2 elf (and call it 3/4 elf or 7/8 elf or something) and avoid the xp penalties. But to me that feels a bit like stretching things too far.

Taking CoT for Great Wis in epic levels gives more feats than cleric alone, but more cleric levels give a stronger caster.
To me CoT, even as CoS, is problematic from alignment reasons alone. It would have been different if the class was an alignment independent and general Divine Champion class that could be chosen by evil characters.

If you want to build a dex based human cleric of Shar with monk levels, The shadow priest, or an adaptation of that build is very close to how I envision the build. But I am biased. The cleric of Shar that I talked about in the other thread was a human Shadovar with a dex based Cleric 26/ Monk 9/SD 5 build.
But there are many other ways to build with human.

My advice, if you want to build Viconia, is to stick with elf and see what you can do within that frame. Cleric is a great class on its own. If you want to add anything else, only do it for a very good reason, and keep it simple.

Mick

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
You really are determined to be a "thwart, disnatured torment unto me" aren't you, Mick? See, that's how bad it's got - going all Shakespearean on you now!

My initial elven (or elvish?) stat spread was Str 12 (or 10), Dex 16, Con 10 (or 12), Wis 16, Int 14, Cha 8. I dumped the Charisma because I'd already discounted BG and in the other BG you always got clobbered with a -2 to reputation when taking in a drow, so thought it justified. Vicky's BG2 stat spread was Str 10, Dex 19, Con 8, Wis 18, Int 16, Cha 14, so I tried to balance it similarly (given what I've said about Cha).

And while it's very helpful to know that Dex 26, Wis 26 is "quite all right", that's not what Viconia is, is it? Anomen is "quite all right", Vicky is exceptional. But I don't see her as an assassin, sorry.

By my reckoning, in a build with at least 29 levels of Cleric and 10 CoT (where all CoT bonus feats are reached in epic levels), there are 10 natural stat bumps, up to 8 bonus feats in Wis (5 from CoT, 3 from Cleric), then - taking Armour Skin, Epic Prowess and EWF out of the general feat pool - a further 4 Great Wis or Dex feats are available. By my count, that's 22. Done equally, that would give a final Dex and Wis of 27 each. However, my issue (one of many) is what I gain and lose from tilting the scales one way or the other.

At the moment, and remembering how I played Viconia in BG2, I'm tempted by the more Wis, less Dex route, but I'm in new and empty waters here.

And a single level of Rogue at 37 remains appealing (for all the gods' sake, please don't tell Max).

Cheers, and thanks so much for the opportunity!

EDIT: Oh, and I think I've finally made up my mind: a vengeful, offensive cleric is where Viconia should be going (and I don't want any childish giggles about "offensive", all right? You think this is fun?). I'm wanting bucketfuls of SoVs raining down on the rat-bastards!

So, maybe I'm right in wanting more WIS, and maybe I'm wrong in wanting CoT for more of a melee presence. Who'd have thought it?

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content: CoT is more than simply wisdom buffs and melee presence, he strengthens your saves as well, which is always a good thing. Your only other option to get good saving throws apart from CoT would be Blackguard and some investment in charisma, which although a fine choice by itself, will undoubtedly complicate things somewhat.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
If you go for a caster Cleric, how about pure Cleric? You would get 6 Cleric bonus feats, and great spell penetration (against spell resistance), and high WIS would give good DCs against saves. You could still cast buffs on yourself and have a strong melee presence.

If you want to focus on being a melee Cleric, how about Cleric 17 / CoT 3 pre-epic for 1 CoT feat pre-epic and then 7 more CoT in epic levels? You would get 4 CoT feats and 3 Cleric feats in epic levels, which should include EWF, EP, and AS. In that case, bringing WIS to 20 and otherwise going for a high DEX would be the way I would go.

Here's another idea: Make 2 builds, a role-play version that is an accurate representation of Viconia while not being completely awful, and another more powerful version that you would actually want to play.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
OK Stagmeister, enough tormenting now!

I agree with you on making just one build.
A self buffing melee cleric is probably the closest to what you are used to playing. But then again, even a melee cleric has great help from some attack spells.
A caster cleric is probably jumping in at the deep end, since you are unfamiliar with casters. But learning how to play a caster will be rewarding and open up new ways to play this game for you.
And fear not - any normally built cleric is far from squishy! (And even "quite all right" clerics are quite astonishing to play)

If you feel that playing Viconia will add fun to the experience - than build her and play her!
If you want to make things easier for you by adding more freedom to what kind of cleric build you play, then do so!

We will try to nudge you in the right direction, and no more tormenting (hopefully).

Mick

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
At first glance the build looks like an OK cleric build (and that is good in my book).

I have not been able to check the saves yet.
You take CoT pre epic to improve saves and get an extra feat. If you feel feat starved, Toughness not a feat to give priority.
The (possible/probable) tumble dump comes late. Evasion would be nice, and uncanny dodge would also be nice for this dex'er. Uncanny dodge let you use light armor and robes and retain your dexterity AC bonus. You have enough dexterity to wear robes once you buff with cat's. Buffing dexterity will actually improve your AC beyond what you can get from full plate. But you must find room for more rogue levels first if you want UD.

I would use this kind of stat spread for a "general purpose" cleric.
For a pure caster I would take many more cleric levels, maxed wisdom and chosen a spell focus.
For a focused self buffing "melee cleric" I would have stopped wisdom at max 20 and taken between 15 (econo-cleric) and 24 (undispellable) cleric levels.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
I like the new stat spread. I also like the earlier AS. She now has a really good AB & AC for a combat-cleric in addition to her strong saving throws. I am not gonna lie, both melee damage & spells are weak though so you are gonna rely on DF & Darkfire & special properties of the weapons. The way to do this properly with a cleric is to use a "stat-stick" & then buff the heck out of it. In high-magic modules (pretty much everything that exists really, even Aielund is high-magic & HoTU or SoF are absurd magic) that won't be necessary but it is good to know how to do that.

Here is an example, take a magic weapon that has extra damage on it & any other useful properties such as the "rapier of the high road", it doesn't matter if the enchantment is low. Then cast GMW on it to make it +5, then Darkfire to add 1d6 +10 fire damage, then Divine Favour (extended) to add another +5 damage to it, you now have a +5 keen Rapier with 1d6 acid & 11-16 fire damage on it plus your strength bonus. Divine Power will automatically make your strength be "18" base so if you have cast empowered bull's before that, it is almost guaranteed to have 24 strength as well. And that is how clerics do damage out of nothing, really. It might seem "too much to bother with at first, but once you put your extended & empowered spells in your hotkey bar they are all ready to be used with just the press of a key.

And since I was talking about rapiers, they are finessable and with the best crit-range so you could always go "extend-spell, finesse, exotic weapons, empower-spell, focus in rapiers" & forget about the IC: mace.

Hit points are fine considering your high AC & the ability to heal yourself with just a spell. Don't forget that from 9th level onwards you will also have the ability to cast empower "endurance" for +6 vitality that will last until your next rest. Cleric buffs (especially, extended ones) are nothing like potions you find in the game with their pitiful 3rd caster-level, this is the real thing.

posts.author: Valerfor

DC formula for the spells is simple enough.

DC= 10 +spell level +spell focuses (if any) +wisdom modifier.

There is one exception to this (Implosion) that add +3 DC to the total after all other calculations.

Viconia's strongest spells (9th level) will have a DC of (24) with the exception of Implosion that will have a DC of (27). Add plus (6) to those DC's for a maxed-out wisdom score.

And then, there is Harm.
